title: Francesco Calì
text:
Francesco Calì (; 16 May 1882 – 3 September 1949) was an Italian professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player, coach and referee, who played as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a>. He <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captained</a> the <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy national football team</a> in their first ever match, on 15 May 1910.
Early life.
Calì was born in <a href="Riposto">Riposto</a>, <a href="Sicily">Sicily</a> on 16 May 1882, to Bruno Calì, a wine merchant. After pirate assaults on his father's business, he and his family immigrated to Switzerland two years later; he was nicknamed Franz.
Career.
Calì played several games as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29%23Full-back">left-back</a> for Swiss clubs <a href="FC%20Z%C3%BCrich">Zürich</a> and <a href="Urania%20Gen%C3%A8ve%20Sport">Urania Genève Sport</a>. He then played for two rival Genovese teams: <a href="Genoa%20C.F.C.">Genoa</a> and <a href="U.C.%20Sampdoria">Andrea Doria</a>. He was also a referee during his time at Andrea Doria.
Due to his experience as a footballer, as well as his knowledge of several foreign languages, he was selected as the <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy national team</a> <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captain</a>, in their <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team%20records%23Captains">first ever game</a> on 15 May 1910, in Milan against <a href="France%20national%20football%20team">France</a>, where Italy won 6–2.
After his retirement as a player, he was also chosen several times as a member of the Italian national team technical commission, in 1912, 1914, 1915, 1920 and 1921.
